selected_quotes: Does cognition penetrate vision? Expectations bias visual activity before a stimulus even occurs @NatureNeuro
Yes! Our review paper on expectation in perceptual decision-making, out now
Great review by @flodlan Chris Summerfield in @NatRevNeurosci on the impact of expectation on perceptual decisions
This new Review discusses how expectation modulates perception at both the neural and behavioural level (£)
Expectation in perceptual decision making: neural and computational mechanisms, by Summerfield and de Lange

citation.abstract: Sensory signals are highly structured in both space and time. These structural regularities in visual information allow expectations to form about future stimulation, thereby facilitating decisions about visual features and objects. Here, we discuss how expectation modulates neural signals and behaviour in humans and other primates. We consider how expectations bias visual activity before a stimulus occurs, and how neural signals elicited by expected and unexpected stimuli differ. We discuss how expectations may influence decision signals at the computational level. Finally, we consider the relationship between visual expectation and related concepts, such as attention and adaptation.
citation.title: Expectation in perceptual decision making: neural and computational mechanisms

weibo.summary: 10.15#Nat Rev Neurosci#知觉中的预期效应.信号的时空联系可产生预测.总结脑成像和单细胞研究认为(predictive coding):知觉动因有多层,层越高越复杂.每层知觉基于上层元素时空联系产生预测,预测与下层感觉证据不一致时,预测修正...直至预测与感觉证据产生一致(generative model).http://t.cn/R72Ks5T

news.title: Expectation in perceptual decision making neural and computational mechanisms
news.summary: Visual stimuli can often be predicted by other stimuli in the environment for example a barking sound would predict the sight of a dog but not a cat. In this Review Summerfield and de Lange discuss how expectation modulates neural signals and behaviour in.
